results.title: Way down east [DVD]
results.brief_description: A country girl is tricked into a fake marriage by a lecherous playboy. He deserts her when she becomes pregnant. After the death of the baby she seeks refuge in the house of a puritanical squire. The melodramatic cliche of the original play is transformed, suffused with the timelessness of myth by Griffith and the principal players. The extraordinary delicacy and intensity of Gish is well complemented by the playing of Barthelmess as the country boy. The final scenes of fragility against the elements in the blizzard and on the icefloe (filmed at some risk to Gish and Barthelmess) is a tour-de-force of staging, composition and editing. Based on the play by Lottie Blair Parker, William Brady and Joseph R. Grisner. Cast includes Lillian Gish, Richard Barthelmess and Lowell Sherman. With musical soundtrack recorded in 1928 by Louis Silvers. This version was fully restored by film historian David Shepard.

results.title: Nosferatu [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Frederick Murnau, Albin Grau, Enrico Dieckman and Prana-Film
results.brief_description: Hutter is a German real estate agent newly married and extremely excited about his latest transaction, selling a property to the reclusive Herr Orlok, who lives in remote Transylvania. Despite the warnings of the local peasants and the imploring of his wife, Hutter travels to Orlok’s castle where he begins to suspect that his client may not be of this world. Orlok travels by boat to Bremen where he prepares to realise the evil intentions he nurses for Hutter’s beautiful young wife. Although the plot is quite close to that of Bram Stoker’s Dracula, the emotional and intellectual emphases are different. The figure of Count Orlok resembling an animated corpse is far from Stoker’s well-groomed, demonic vampire and Nosferatu exhibits none of the shadow play of Caligari. Director Murnau showed how the fantastic film could gain from the use of real settings and the imaginative treatment of space. This feeling of landscape became a central element of the classic vampire film.

results.title: Eyes of Laura Mars [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Irvin Kershner, Jon Peters and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Laura Mars is a high profile fashion photographer who specialises in settings of urban murder and violence. When she becomes plagued by visions of “real” murders, Laura dismisses them as a by-product of her work. However, tension starts to mount when she begins to telepathically witness the bloody murders of her friends and colleagues, as seen through the eyes of the actual killer. Cast includes: Faye Dunaway, Tommy Lee Jones, Brad Dourif, Rene Auberjonois and Raul Julia.

results.title: Living out loud [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Richard LaGravenese, Danny DeVito, Michael Shamberg, Stacey Sher, Jersey Films and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Living out loud was the directorial debut for screenwriter, Richard LaGravenese, who based this script on two stories by Anton Chekhov. Judith Nelson is a genteel uptown New Yorker, devastated by the news that her husband is leaving her for another woman. The aftershocks of this event forces Judith to question her personal presumptions and life choices that lead her to this juncture. We witness Judith’s inner turmoil, coming to terms with the lie of her marriage and the challenge to find an identity, other than wife, which will enable her to relate to others. A part of Judith’s journey is the blossoming of her friendship with Pat, the elevator operator in her building who is deeply indebted to shady gamblers, estranged from his wife and facing the death of his young daughter. Judith’s financial assistance of Pat and potential romance, as well as her friendship with a sultry nightclub singer, directs her on a path that crystallises her ambitions. This is a sensitively written film, impressive in its observations of the emotional lives of the protagonists and the struggles that ensue.

results.title: The Awful truth
results.brief_description: One of the classic screwball comedies of the 1930s, “The Awful truth” was nominated for six Academy Awards, winning an Oscar for director Leo McCarey. This was the third time the story had been brought to the screen, this version particularly working because of the improvisation encouraged of the cast and crew. The actors’ state of bewilderment and the humour born from this is reinforced by the fact that much of their dialogue is ad-libbed. The story centres around New York couple the Warriners (Cary Grant and Irene Dunne), who both suspect the infidelities of the other. They agree to a trial divorce, but cannot agree on who will get custody of their pet dog Mr Smith. What follows is a battlefield of witty dialogue, slapstick, sophisticated New York versus Southern manners and sublime bickering, while the Warriners attempt to sabotage each other’s new romances and ultimately try to reunite.

results.title: One deadly summer = L'Ete Meurtrier
results.creator_credit: Jean Becker, Christine Beyout, CAPAC, Societe Nouvelle de Cinematographie and TF1 Films productions
results.brief_description: Isabelle Adjani plays Elle, a fiery nineteen-year-old woman who moves to a small provincial French town with her introverted German born mother and reclusive disabled father. Elle is a confident woman who wantonly displays her sexy body and soon has every man in town captivated. Alain Souchon plays Pin Pon, a mechanic who falls into an obsession with Elle, and agonizes over invalidated rumours of other men’s conquests of her. Motivated by revenge, Elle easily draws Pin Pon into her orbit and soon moves in with him, despite the disapproval of his pious mother. Through a series of flashbacks it is revealed that twenty years earlier, in the post war period, Elle’s mother was brutally gang raped by several French deliverymen. Elle, tortured by issues of her parentage, is driven to avenge her mother’s rape but is also stirred by secrets from her own past that exacerbate her increasingly unstable mental condition. The switching of first person narration allows for multiple viewpoints to be appreciated by the viewer. This is a tragedy about vengeance, obsessive behaviour and neuroses. (Awards: Adjani won a Cesar for Best supporting actress, 1983). In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Closely observed trains = Ostre sledovane vlaky [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Jiri Menzel, Zdenek Oves and Barrandov Studios
results.brief_description: During the German occupation, a young man, Milos, (Vaclav Neckar) works as a trainee railway guard in a country station. He has only one thing on his mind; to lose his virginity, possibly with the wife of the station master (Libuse Havelkova). His attempts take him through the trauma of premature ejaculation, an attemped suicide and finally success with a member of the Underground movement, before tragedy strikes. “Closely observed trains” is adapted from a novel by Bohumil Hrabal. This film is one of the finest achievements of the Czech “New Wave” and was the second Czech film to win an Oscar for best foreign film in 1967. The film was banned after the Soviet invasion of 1969 as “pornographic”. Also known as “Closely watched trains”. In Czech with English subtitles.

results.title: Naked states [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Arlene Donnelly, David Nelson, Jen Chaiken, Chaiken Films, Cinemax Reel Life and Juntos Films
results.brief_description: Spencer Tunick, internationally famous for taking public nude photographs ‘en masse’ has travelled the world photographing individuals and groups. “Naked states” is the documentary that helped make Tunick famous, chronicling his first major project, photographing people posing naked across 48 different states in America. This biographical documentary explores Tunick’s influences and motivations, commenting on the artistic process and the issue nudity. This rich documentary offers a sometimes intimate journey into the reasons why the subjects chose to pose naked. What is revealed, surprisingly, is not naked bodies but the breadth of difference of the people that make up our society and a generous spirit usually concealed. Contains nudity which may offend some viewers.

results.title: Top dog = Wodzirej [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Just how far will one person go to achieve their goal? For Danielak (Jerzy Stuhr), a variety host/entertainer, there appears to be no boundaries or limits out there which will stop him from being the MC of an upcoming gala ball in a brand new hotel. Danielak is prepared to lie, deceive, bribe and bluff his way through the chain of authority in order to eliminate his competition. Realistic in style, “Top dog” is a biting commentary on 70s communist Poland, and in particular, the bureaucratic State departments and State owned companies. Director Feliks Falk is representative of the 70s new Polish cinema, the “cinema of moral anxiety” and for this, if for no other reason, “Top dog” is both intriguing and entertaining. Cast also includes Slawa Kwasniewska, Wiktor Sadecki, Michal Tarkowski, Ewa Kolasinska, Ryszard Kotys, Jerzy Kryszak. In Polish with English subtitles.

results.title: Hotel splendide
results.creator_credit: Terence Gross, Ildiko Kemeny, Film Four International, Renegade Films and TOC Films
results.brief_description: In the middle of nowhere, surrounded by sea, towers a large gothic family-run hotel cum health resort. It is run entirely under the shadow of “Mother”, the family’s recently deceased matriarch who upheld stringency and regiment as the path to purity and well-being. Despite the contradictions, for example, that the patients never leave the hotel cured, the hotel’s staff run things as mother would have: Ronald, the son/chef, prepares food that resembles cardboard; Cora, the daughter/therapist, treats patients stringently; and Dezmond, the hotel’s manager and mummy’s dearest, ensures everyone follows suit. Director Terence Gross delights in the oddness of this enclosed world, creating a carnivalesque universe reminiscent of the work of Jean-Pierre Jeunet and Marc Caro. Into this world of stark repression, enters Kath, the hotel’s former chef and lover of Ronald who Mother previously banished. Kath’s ‘balanced’ perspective upsets the order of things and ultimately triggers the hotel’s destruction. “Hotel Splendide” is British to the core. The hotel is easily a metaphor for the Victorian era, a world ruled by repression. And reminiscent of Greenaway, Gross critiques this world to show the aberrances and contradictions it gives rise to. Its storybook fashion, evident in its mythical quality, eccentric characters and deep, dank secrets, ensures a heightened and colourful critique of perversions and oddities that arise from an isolated community. The performances also fit this style superbly. Cast includes Toni Collette, Daniel Craig, Katrin Cartlidge and Stephen Tompkinson.

The performances also fit this style superbly. Cast includes Toni Collette, Daniel Craig, Katrin Cartlidge and Stephen Tompkinson.
description_for_label: In the middle of nowhere, surrounded by sea, towers a large gothic family-run hotel cum health resort. It is run entirely under the shadow of “Mother”, the family’s recently deceased matriarch who upheld stringency and regiment as the path to purity and well-being. Despite the contradictions, for example, that the patients never leave the hotel cured, the hotel’s staff run things as mother would have: Ronald, the son/chef, prepares food that resembles cardboard; Cora, the daughter/therapist, treats patients stringently; and Dezmond, the hotel’s manager and mummy’s dearest, ensures everyone follows suit. Director Terence Gross delights in the oddness of this enclosed world, creating a carnivalesque universe reminiscent of the work of Jean-Pierre Jeunet and Marc Caro. Into this world of stark repression, enters Kath, the hotel’s former chef and lover of Ronald who Mother previously banished. Kath’s ‘balanced’ perspective upsets the order of things and ultimately triggers the hotel’s destruction. “Hotel Splendide” is British to the core.
